metadata.case_name: Appellant (Mining Proprietor) v. Assistant Collector of Customs and Central Excise, Raipur

facts.text: The appellant is a mining proprietor and holds several manganese mines in different States. He has also been doing business in many articles apart from being an exporter of manganese ore.

On information alleged to have been received to the effect that the appellant was in possession of a large quantity of undeclared gold the Assistant Collector of Customs and Central Excise Raipur issued an authorization under r. 126L(42) of the Defence of India Amendment Rules, 1963 (Gold Control Rules), for searching the premises of the appellant.
Pursuant to that authorization, the appellants premises were searched and as a result of the search gold and other articles, foreign currency and other documents were seized.

The appellant filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Bombay Nagpur Bench challenging the validity of the said search and the seizure of the articles and documents belonging to him (Special Civil Application 459 of 1963).
The petition was heard along with similar petitions filed by other persons whose premises were likewise searched and goods and documents seized therefrom.
The High Court dismissed all the petitions on February 24, 25, 1964.

The several petitioners before the High Court, along with the appellant, preferred appeals to this Court and the appeals other than that filed by the appellant were heard by this Court in Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes, Superintendent Prevention, Central Excise Nagpur (A.I.R. 1966 S.C. 1209).
Three years have elapsed since the documents were seized and nothing further has been done in the matter.

legal_issues.text: Whether the search of the premises of the appellant and the seizure of the articles and the documents found therein were valid.
Whether the Assistant Collector and the officer authorized by him to make the search acted with mala fides.
Whether the authorization under s. 105 of the Customs Act lacked the required 'reason to believe'.
Whether the authorization must give reasons for belief and particulars of the nature of the goods and documents.
Whether seizure under s. 110 was valid as performed by a 'proper officer' per s. 2(34).
Whether the search complied with provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure as incorporated by s. 105(2) of the Customs Act.
Whether s. 105 of the Customs Act confers unguided and arbitrary power violating Art. 14 of the Constitution.
Whether the Assistant Collector had material to sustain reasonable belief.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Assistant Collector and the officer authorized by him to make the search acted with mala fides.

Under s. 105 of the Customs Act, the Assistant Collector shall have reason to believe that some goods are secreted before he can authorize any officer of Customs to search, but the authorization did not say that he had reason to believe so.
The Assistant Collector should give reasons for his belief and particulars of the nature of the goods and documents, otherwise the officer may make a roving search.
Under s. 110(3), only a proper officer per s. 2(34) can seize; the Collector must seize personally or the Board assign functions, not the Collector.
Search void as provisions of CrPC not complied with, particularly s.165(1) requiring recording grounds of belief.
S. 105 confers unguided and arbitrary power on Assistant Collector, subjective satisfaction without policy or control, violating Art.14.
Assistant Collector placed no material before High Court to sustain reasonable belief.

court_reasoning.text: Points considered in Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes (AIR 1966 SC 1209) cannot be reagitated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only peculiar questions to this appeal considered.

court_reasoning.text: Contention of mala fides has no substance; High Court considered evidence and rejected it; no justification to differ.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence does not support mala fides.

court_reasoning.text: Though words 'reason to believe' not embodied, phraseology used ('information has been laid... it has been made to appear...') means the same in effect and substance.

S.105 does not require giving reasons or particulars of documents (known only after search); must indicate broadly nature of goods/documents; here, specified contraband goods/documents in office/residential premises, sufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No compulsion to state reasons; specifications adequate.

court_reasoning.text: 'Proper officer' per s.2(34) includes those assigned functions by Board or Collector; both can assign.
S.105 Act and s.165(1) CrPC for different situations; no requirement to record reasons under s.105 as under urgent CrPC search without warrant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisions not analogous; no recording required.

court_reasoning.text: S.105 has policy (search for confiscable goods/documents relevant to proceedings); checks: must prove belief if challenged, send record to Collector per s.165(5) CrPC via s.105(2), criminal liability under s.136(2); not arbitrary, does not offend Art.14.
High Court held on material that Assistant Collector acted with reasonable belief; no justification to interfere.

holdings.text: Search and seizure under s.105 Customs Act valid; authorization adequate despite not explicitly stating 'reason to believe'; no need to record reasons or give document particulars.
Collector can assign 'proper officer' functions under s.2(34).
No CrPC s.165(1) recording required for s.105 search.

precedents_cited.case_name: Durg Prasad v. H.R. Gomes, Superintendent Prevention, Central Excise Nagpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissed similar contentions; points therein not reagitated.

statutes_cited.name: Customs Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs authorization, search, seizure by proper officer; criminal checks on abuse.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Amendment Rules, 1963 (Gold Control Rules)
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorization for search issued under this.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied so far as may be to searches under Customs Act s.105(2), but s.165(1) recording not required.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court petition under Art.226; s.105 not violative of Art.14.

outcome.summary: The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs. Noted that three years have elapsed since seizure and nothing further done.

key_quotes.text: Though the words reason to believe are not in terms embodied in the authorisation, the phraseology used in effect and substance meant the same thing.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We cannot, therefore, say that s. 105 offends Art. 14 of the Constitution.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the result, the appeal fails and is dismissed with costs.
key_quotes.speaker: court
